inference:
First, we find the inverse of $f$.

If $x\le 1$, then $f(x)=2-x$. Solving for $x$, we get $x=2-f(x)$. So, the inverse of $f$ on the interval $x\le 1$ is $f^{-1}(x)=2-x$.

If $x>1$, then $f(x)=2x-x^2$. Solving for $x$, we get $x=1\pm \sqrt{1+f(x)}$. So, the inverse of $f$ on the interval $x>1$ is $f^{-1}(x)=1\pm \sqrt{1+f(x)}$.

Now, we can evaluate $f^{-1}(-3)+f^{-1}(0)+f^{-1}(3)$.

Since $-3<-1$, we have $f^{-1}(-3)=2-(-3)=5$.

Since $0\le 1$, we have $f^{-1}(0)=2-0=2$.

Since $3>1$, we have $f^{-1}(3)=1\pm \sqrt{1+3}=1\pm 2$. So, $f^{-1}(3)=-1$ or $f^{-1}(3)=3$.

Therefore, $f^{-1}(-3)+f^{-1}(0)+f^{-1}(3)=5+2+(-1)=6$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{6}$. I hope it is correct.

If $x\le 1$, then $f(x)=2-x$. Solving for $x$, we get $x=2-f(x)$. So, the inverse of $f$ on the interval $x\le 1$ is $f^{-1}(x)=2-x$.

If $x>1$, then $f(x)=2x-x^2$. Solving for $x$, we get $x=1\pm \sqrt{1+f(x)}$. So, the inverse of $f$ on the interval $x>1$ is $f^{-1}(x)=1\pm \sqrt{1+f(x)}$.

Now, we can evaluate $f^{-1}(-3)+f^{-1}(0)+f^{-1}(3)$.

Since $-3<-1$, we have $f^{-1}(-3)=2-(-3)=5$.

Since $0\le 1$, we have $f^{-1}(0)=2-0=2$.

Since $3>1$, we have $f^{-1}(3)=1\pm \sqrt{1+3}=1\pm 2$. So, $f^{-1}(3)=-1$ or $f^{-1}(3)=3$.
